The best way of answering the longer questions is just to think carefully about basic concepts that you have learnt, then how you could apply them to the problem
Ask yourself, what use may this concept help with this question?
Then write that idea out onto the paper (try not to use too much of the page)
Then think of other concepts that could extend the concept
Another thing, the MAT tends to present problems, as if it were to be someone trying to work with you
So whatever have they given you, try to think about what limitations you have with the current concept you are given
Then what other concepts you can link it towards in order to achieve what you wanted
Also, if you are running out of options, the brute force approach to questions is sometimes fine
Like finding trends within sequences or expanding huge brackets, it is fine
As long as you believe it could support you, it is ok
Its best to allocate most of the time to the long Qs rather than the multiple choice
If you find a multiple Q too tough to answer, definitely skip and answer it when you have time
It is a 1 in 5 chance in you getting the Q right anyway, so if you ever are on your last 5 mins, that is probably the best time to answer those skipped multiple choice Qs (It is best to skip 1-2 Qs)
If you have skipped more than 3, allocate more time (whatever you believe) to those multiple choice Qs
